From: Robert Sartin <sartin@...>

If the Exception indicates the setUp failed, propagate it.

I usually write setUp as follows:

public void setUp() throws Exception {
  super.setUp();
  // Do stuff I need
}

The super.setUp call ensures that if I subclass (or later refactor to
subclass) a TestCase that has setUp requirements, that things will
still work. The throws Exception allows any failure during setUp to be
reported as a test Error (rather than Failure) by JUnit.

Similarly, I often allow individiual tests to propagate Exception back
to JUnit and let it report the Error. As a style issue, I sometimes
catch semi-expected, but incorrect, Exception instances and cause them
to be reported as a Failure. That gets the Failure (test failed) vs.
Error (something went wrong in the test that might be environmental
rather than broken software) reporting by JUnit to be correct.

Regards,

Rob
